bibliographic_metadata.Title: Determination of Predictive Variables in Mineral Prospectivity Mapping Using Supervised and Unsupervised Methods
bibliographic_metadata.Author: Chengbin Wang, Jianguo Chen, Yongpeng Ouyang

abstract: This study presents a comparative analysis using supervised and unsupervised methods to determine predictive variables (PVs) for mineral prospectivity mapping. Twelve variables were created based on a mineral deposit model, and methods such as recursive feature elimination (RFE) and sparse principal components analysis (SPCA) were employed to identify PVs. The weights-of-evidence and Random Forest methods were used to integrate these variables into a probability map of mineral prospectivity, evaluated using the receiver operating characteristic curve. The findings highlight the importance of PV determination in enhancing mineral prospectivity predictions.
methodology: supervised > tree-based > random forest; knowledge-driven > probabilistic > weights of evidence (WofE)
key_points: SPCA and RFE were used to determine predictive variables for mineral prospectivity.
The study area is located in the Jiangnan porphyry-skarn tungsten belt.
Geological, geochemical, and geophysical variables were integrated for mapping.
The Random Forest method showed high performance in mineral prospectivity prediction.
PV determination is crucial for improving prediction accuracy.
